title: A Unifying Israeli President Looks to Break Election Impasse
text:
TEL AVIV—The task of breaking Israel’s election deadlock falls to President Reuven Rivlin, a grandfatherly national figure who has called for unity but faces an uphill battle as all sides dig in.

On Sunday, Mr. Rivlin, 79 years old, is due to launch talks with the nine political parties elected to Israel’s Knesset after the vote this week showed no clear winner. He will be seeking to decide who should get the first shot at forming a government, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu or former Gen. Benny Gantz, leader of a new centrist party, Blue and White.

Elected to the largely ceremonial role in 2014 after a long career as a lawmaker with the Likud Party of Mr. Netanyahu, Mr. Rivlin has developed a reputation as being above Israel’s fractious politics. He is pushing for a broad coalition of parties from across the political spectrum to run Israel, known as a unity government, though he can’t force any such move.

Mr. Rivlin has up to a week-and-a-half to choose a candidate, who then gets up to six weeks to form a government, pointing to an extended period of political uncertainty at a time of rising tension in the Middle East. The vote was the second this year, coming just months after an April election left Mr. Netanyahu unable to form a government.

The president and other Israeli leaders are urging a swift return to normalcy. Mr. Rivlin will work as quickly as possible to end the political instability, Harel Tobi, the director of the President’s Residence, told Israel’s Army Radio on Friday.

The difficulty of Mr. Rivlin’s task became clearer on Friday as official results rolled in and Israel’s parties remained hunkered in their blocs.

Mr. Gantz declared victory after his party came out of the election with the most seats, with 33, to 31 for Likud, according to near-final results released by the election committee. But Mr. Gantz doesn’t have nearly the number of promises of support as Mr. Netanyahu, who has pledges from right-wing and religious parties that secure him 55 seats, just six short of the 61 needed to form a governing coalition.

Avigdor Lieberman, this election’s kingmaker because he wouldn’t align with anyone, refused Friday to commit his party’s eight seats to Mr. Gantz for now. The Joint List, a union of Arab parties with 13 seats, has also withheld support from Mr. Gantz, so far.

Mr. Rivlin has used his public pulpit to speak against Israel’s increasing “tribalization” into four groups—Arab, secular, ultra-Orthodox and the nationalist religious—who hold separate values and rarely interact.

In a sign of the respect for Mr. Rivlin, he has support among both backers of annexing the West Bank and Arab leaders who say he is among the few right-wing officials who shows concern for Israel’s Arab citizens.

Mr. Rivlin nominated Mr. Netanyahu to lead the government in 2015 and 2019, but he has also expressed worry about Israeli society growing increasingly divisive under the prime minister’s stewardship.

Though Blue and White won the most seats and Mr. Netanyahu had the most commitments, Mr. Rivlin’s job goes beyond judging who has the most pledges or the largest party, Mr. Tobi said.

“He will choose the candidate who is most likely to form a government,” Mr. Tobi said.

The president hinted Thursday that he would prefer a unity government joining Likud and Blue and White. Gideon Rahat, a professor at Hebrew University and director of the political reform program at the Israel Democracy Institute, said he believes Mr. Rivlin will try to push Messrs. Gantz and Netanyahu to agree to form a unity government with a rotation of the prime minister’s seat.

Mr. Gantz has said he won’t serve with Mr. Netanyahu as long as the prime minister faces indictment on bribery and fraud charges, allegations the prime minister denies.

“Because he has a role in deciding who to nominate and form a government, Rivlin has an important say here,” said Mr. Rahat. “He can pressure them by saying in the name of the people, we don’t want third elections, the people say they want a unity government.”

Mr. Rivlin is expected to wrap up talks with the parties by Wednesday and then will have one week to choose a potential future prime minister. If that candidate fails, Mr. Rivlin would give a different candidate 28 days to form a government. If talks fail again, elections would be called unless 61 lawmakers come together and choose a leader.
description: The task of breaking Israel’s election deadlock falls to President Reuven Rivlin, a grandfatherly national figure who has called for unity but faces an uphill battle as all sides dig in.
